data.title: Unionpedia, the concept map
data.meta_description: A chaplain is a cleric (such as a minister, priest, pastor, rabbi, or imam), or a lay representative of a religious tradition, attached to a secular institution such as a hospital, prison, military unit, school, business, police department, fire department, university, or private chapel. 833 relations.

Aarhus Cathedral

Aarhus Cathedral (Aarhus Domkirke) is a cathedral in Aarhus, Denmark.

See Chaplain and Aarhus Cathedral

Abbé Faria

Abbé Faria, or Abbé (Abbot) José Custódio de Faria, (31 May 1756 – 20 September 1819), was a Luso-Goan Catholic monk who was one of the pioneers of the scientific study of hypnotism, following on from the work of Franz Mesmer.

See Chaplain and Abbé Faria

Abbé Pierre

Abbé Pierre, OFM Cap, (born Henri Marie Joseph Grouès; 5 August 1912 – 22 January 2007) was a French Catholic priest, member of the Resistance during World War II, and deputy of the Popular Republican Movement (MRP).

See Chaplain and Abbé Pierre

Abbot

Abbot, meaning father, is an ecclesiastical title given to the male head of a monastery in various traditions, including Christianity.

See Chaplain and Abbot

Abel de Gullane

Abel de Gullane was a 13th-century Bishop of St Andrews.

See Chaplain and Abel de Gullane

Abraham Baldwin

Abraham Baldwin (November 22, 1754March 4, 1807) was an American minister, Patriot, politician, and Founding Father.

See Chaplain and Abraham Baldwin

Abraham of Strathearn

Abraham was an early 13th-century Scottish cleric who held the position of Bishop of Dunblane.

See Chaplain and Abraham of Strathearn

Abram Joseph Ryan

The Rev. Abram Joseph Ryan (February 5, 1838 – April 22, 1886) was an American poet, an active proponent of the Confederate States of America, and a Catholic priest.

See Chaplain and Abram Joseph Ryan

Achille Liénart

Achille Liénart (7 February 1884—15 February 1973) was a French Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church.

See Chaplain and Achille Liénart

Adam Adamandy Kochański

Adam Adamandy Kochański (5 August 1631 – 17 May 1700) was a Polish mathematician.

See Chaplain and Adam Adamandy Kochański

Adam Ferguson

Adam Ferguson, FRSE (Scottish Gaelic: Adhamh MacFhearghais), also known as Ferguson of Raith (1 JulyGregorian Calendar/20 JuneJulian Calendar 1723 – 22 February 1816), was a Scottish philosopher and historian of the Scottish Enlightenment.

See Chaplain and Adam Ferguson

Adam Maida

Adam Joseph Maida (born March 18, 1930) is an American cardinal prelate of the Roman Catholic Church.

See Chaplain and Adam Maida

Adolf Stoecker

Adolf Stoecker (December 11, 1835 – February 2, 1909) was the court chaplain to Kaiser Wilhelm I, a politician, and a German Lutheran theologian who founded one of the first Christian Social Gospel political parties in Germany, the Christian Social Party.

See Chaplain and Adolf Stoecker

AfterMASH

AfterMASH is an American sitcom produced as a spin-off and continuation of M*A*S*H that aired on CBS from September 26, 1983, to May 31, 1985.

See Chaplain and AfterMASH

Agostino Gemelli

Agostino Gemelli, O.F.M., (18 January 1878 – 15 July 1959) was an Italian Franciscan friar, physician and psychologist, who was also the founder and first Rector of Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore of Milan (Catholic University of the Sacred Heart).

See Chaplain and Agostino Gemelli

Agunah

Agunah (עגונה, plural: agunot (עגונות); literally "anchored" or "chained") is a halakhic term for a Jewish woman who is "chained" to her marriage.

See Chaplain and Agunah

Agustín de Iturbide

Agustín Cosme Damián de Iturbide y Arámburu (27 September 178319 July 1824), also known as Augustine of Mexico, was a Mexican army general and politician.

See Chaplain and Agustín de Iturbide

Ahmed F. Mehalba

Ahmed Fathy Mehalba was a United States Department of Defense civilian translator/ interrogator who was accused of lying to government agents and removing classified documents from the Guantanamo Bay detention facility.

See Chaplain and Ahmed F. Mehalba

Air Force Officer Training School

Officer Training School (OTS) is a United States Air Force commissioning program located at Maxwell Air Force Base in Montgomery, Alabama.

See Chaplain and Air Force Officer Training School

Air Force Specialty Code

The Air Force Specialty Code (AFSC) is an alphanumeric code used by the United States Air Force to identify a specific job.

See Chaplain and Air Force Specialty Code

Air Training Corps

The Air Training Corps (ATC) is a British volunteer-military youth organisation, sponsored by the Ministry of Defence and the Royal Air Force.

See Chaplain and Air Training Corps

Alasdair Morrison (banker)

Alasdair Morrison is currently a private investor, an Independent Non-Executive Director of Pacific Basin Shipping and of the Mass Transit Railway Corporation in Hong Kong.

See Chaplain and Alasdair Morrison (banker)

Albert Gregory Meyer

Albert Gregory Meyer (March 9, 1903 – April 9, 1965) was an American prelate of the Catholic Church.

See Chaplain and Albert Gregory Meyer

Aleksey Kuropatkin

Aleksey Nikolayevich Kuropatkin (Алексе́й Никола́евич Куропа́ткин; March 29, 1848January 16, 1925) was the Russian Imperial Minister of War from 1898 to 1904, and often held responsible for major Russian defeats in the Russo-Japanese War, most notably at the Battle of Mukden and the Battle of Liaoyang.

See Chaplain and Aleksey Kuropatkin

Alexander Macdonell (bishop)

Bishop Alexander Macdonell (born 17 July 1762, Glen Urquhart, Inchlaggan, Scotland - died 14 January 1840) was the first Roman Catholic bishop of Kingston, Upper Canada.

See Chaplain and Alexander Macdonell (bishop)

Alexander Webster

Rev Alexander Webster DD (170825 January 1784) was a Scottish writer and minister, who served as Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland in 1753.

See Chaplain and Alexander Webster

Alfred A. Sanelli

Brigadier General Alfred A. Sanelli, Pennsylvania Guard (May 1, 1921 – December 12, 2005).

See Chaplain and Alfred A. Sanelli

Alfred E. Steele

Alfred E. Steele (born January 22, 1954) is an American Democratic Party politician, who served in the New Jersey General Assembly starting in 1996, where he represented the 35th legislative district.

See Chaplain and Alfred E. Steele

Almoner

An almoner is a chaplain or church officer who originally was in charge of distributing money to the deserving poor.

See Chaplain and Almoner

Alonso Manso

Alonso Manso (1460 – September 27, 1539) was a Roman Catholic prelate who served as the first Bishop of Puerto Rico (1511-1539) (in Latin) and as the eighth governor of Puerto Rico.

See Chaplain and Alonso Manso

Aloys Karl Ohler

Aloys Karl Ohler was a German Catholic cleric and educationist.

See Chaplain and Aloys Karl Ohler

Aloysius Schmitt

Father Aloysius H. Schmitt (December 4, 1909 – December 7, 1941) was a Roman Catholic priest of the Archdiocese of Dubuque, who served as a chaplain in the United States Navy at the beginning of World War II.

See Chaplain and Aloysius Schmitt

Altar stone

An altar stone is a piece of natural stone containing relics in a cavity and intended to serve as the essential part of an altar for the celebration of Mass in the Roman Catholic Church.

See Chaplain and Altar stone

Alys ferch Owain Glyndŵr

Alys ferch Owain Glyndŵr was one of the daughters of Margaret Hanmer and Owain Glyndŵr, the disinherited prince of the old Welsh royal house of Powys Fadog, who led a major revolt in Wales between 1400 and ca.

See Chaplain and Alys ferch Owain Glyndŵr

American Humanist Association

The American Humanist Association (AHA) is an educational organization in the United States that advances secular humanism, a philosophy of life that, without theism or other supernatural beliefs, affirms the ability and responsibility of human beings to lead personal lives of ethical fulfillment that aspire to the greater good of humanity.

See Chaplain and American Humanist Association

American Secular Union

The American Secular Union (ASU, also sometimes called the "American Secular Union and Freethought Federation") espoused secularism and freethought at the end of the 19th century in the United States of America.

See Chaplain and American Secular Union

Ancient See of Børglum

The ancient bishopric of Børglum, sometimes also known as the bishopric of Vendsyssel, seated latterly at Børglum in Denmark, comprised the ancient districts of Vendsyssel and Thy, which between them included the whole of the north of the Jutland peninsula beyond the Limfjord.

See Chaplain and Ancient See of Børglum

Anders Chydenius

Anders Chydenius (26 February 1729 – 1 February 1803) was a Finnish priest and a member of the Swedish Riksdag, and is known as the leading classical liberal of Nordic history.

See Chaplain and Anders Chydenius

André Thevet

André Thevet (1516 – 23 November 1590) was a French Franciscan priest, explorer, cosmographer and writer who travelled to Brazil in the 16th century.

See Chaplain and André Thevet

Andrew Lang (basketball)

Andrew Charles Lang Jr. (born June 28, 1966) is a retired American professional basketball player who played in the NBA.

See Chaplain and Andrew Lang (basketball)

Andrew Linzey

Andrew Linzey (born 2 February 1952) is a British Anglican priest, theologian, author, and prominent figure in the Christian vegetarian movement.

See Chaplain and Andrew Linzey

Andrew Stone (MP)

Andrew Stone (4 February 1703 – 17 December 1773) was a significant figure in the British royal circle in the 18th century and a Member of Parliament.

See Chaplain and Andrew Stone (MP)

Angelo Buccarello

Angelo Buccarello (born 1942) is a member of the Roman Catholic clergy known for his founding of the Catholic Chaplaincy for Prisons.

See Chaplain and Angelo Buccarello

Anglican Church in Aotearoa, New Zealand and Polynesia

The Anglican Church in Aotearoa, New Zealand and Polynesia, formerly the Church of the Province of New Zealand, is a province of the Anglican Communion serving New Zealand, Fiji, Tonga, Samoa, and the Cook Islands.

See Chaplain and Anglican Church in Aotearoa, New Zealand and Polynesia

Anglican Church of Southern Africa

The Anglican Church of Southern Africa, known until 2006 as the Church of the Province of Southern Africa, is the province of the Anglican Communion in the southern part of Africa.

See Chaplain and Anglican Church of Southern Africa

Anglican ministry

The Anglican ministry is both the leadership and agency of Christian service in the Anglican Communion.

See Chaplain and Anglican ministry

Anglican religious order

Anglican religious orders are communities of men or women (or in some cases mixed communities of both sexes) in the Anglican Communion who live under a common rule of life.

See Chaplain and Anglican religious order

Anglo-Saxon Christianity

The history of Christianity in England from the Roman departure to the Norman Conquest is often told as one of conflict between the Celtic Christianity spread by the Irish mission, and Roman Christianity brought across by Augustine of Canterbury.

See Chaplain and Anglo-Saxon Christianity

Animal loss

The death of a pet or an animal to which one has become emotionally bonded can be an intense loss, comparable with the death of a human loved one, or even greater depending on the individual.

See Chaplain and Animal loss

Anno II

Anno II (– 4 December 1075) was Archbishop of Cologne from 1056 until his death.

See Chaplain and Anno II

Answers in Genesis

Answers in Genesis (AiG) is a fundamentalist Christian apologetics parachurch organization.

See Chaplain and Answers in Genesis

Anthony Bevilacqua

Anthony Joseph Bevilacqua (June 17, 1923 – January 31, 2012) was an American cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church.

See Chaplain and Anthony Bevilacqua

Anthony of Sourozh

Metropolitan Anthony of Sourozh (Митропролит Антоний Сурожский, secular name Andrei Borisovich Bloom, Андрей Борисович Блум; 19 June 1914 – 4 August 2003) was best known as a writer and broadcaster on prayer and the Christian life.

See Chaplain and Anthony of Sourozh

Antipope John XVI

John XVI (945 – 1001; born Ιωάννης Φιλάγαθος, Ioannis Philagathos; Giovanni Filagato; Johannes Philagathus) was an antipope from 997 to 998.

See Chaplain and Antipope John XVI

Antonio Baseotto

Antonio Baseotto (b. Añatuya, April 4, 1932) was a Roman Catholic bishop from Argentina.

See Chaplain and Antonio Baseotto

Antti Johannes Rantamaa

Antti Johannes Rantamaa (1904 in Merikarvia – 1987) was a Finnish member of the Finnish Parliament, figure of the Winter War, author and one of the heads of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland.

See Chaplain and Antti Johannes Rantamaa

Anwar al-Awlaki

Anwar al-Awlaki (also spelled al-Aulaqi, al-Awlaqi; أنور العولقي Anwar al-‘Awlaqī; April 21, 1971 – September 30, 2011) was a Yemeni-American Islamist militiant, preacher, and imam.

See Chaplain and Anwar al-Awlaki

APC

APC or Apc may refer to.

See Chaplain and APC

Archbishop of Canterbury

The Archbishop of Canterbury is the senior bishop and principal leader of the Church of England, the symbolic head of the worldwide Anglican Communion and the diocesan bishop of the Diocese of Canterbury.

See Chaplain and Archbishop of Canterbury

Arnulf of Chocques

Arnulf of Chocques (died 1118) was a leading member of the clergy during the First Crusade, being made Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem in 1099 and again from 1112 to 1118.

See Chaplain and Arnulf of Chocques

Arthur Edwards (clergyman)

thumb Arthur Edwards (November 23, 1834–1901) was an American clergyman and editor.

See Chaplain and Arthur Edwards (clergyman)

Arthur Moulton

Arthur Wheelock Moulton (May 3, 1873 – August 18, 1962) was an American Episcopal bishop, born at Worcester, Massachusetts.

See Chaplain and Arthur Moulton

Arthur Young (agriculturist)

Arthur Young (11 September 1741 – 12 April 1820) was an English writer on agriculture, economics, social statistics, and campaigner for the rights of agricultural workers.

See Chaplain and Arthur Young (agriculturist)

Aryeh Levin

Rabbi Aryeh Levin, (אריה לוין; March 22, 1885 - March 28, 1969), known as Reb Aryeh, was an Orthodox rabbi dubbed the "Father of Prisoners" for his visits to members of the Jewish underground imprisoned in the Central Prison of Jerusalem in the Russian Compound during the British Mandate.

See Chaplain and Aryeh Levin

Association of Management, Administrative and Professional Crown Employees of Ontario

The Association of Management, Administrative and Professional Crown Employees of Ontario is a trade union representing public sector employees in the Province of Ontario, Canada.

See Chaplain and Association of Management, Administrative and Professional Crown Employees of Ontario

Aureo Castro

Rev.

See Chaplain and Aureo Castro

Ave Maria University

Ave Maria University (AMU) is a private Catholic university in Southwest Florida, United States, founded in 2003.

See Chaplain and Ave Maria University

Avegno, Switzerland

Avegno was a municipality in the district of Vallemaggia in the canton of Ticino in Switzerland.

See Chaplain and Avegno, Switzerland

Azucena Villaflor

Azucena Villaflor (7 April 1924 in Avellaneda – 10 December 1977) was an Argentine social activist, and one of the founders of the human rights association called Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo, which looked for desaparecidos (victims of forced disappearance during Argentina's Dirty War).

See Chaplain and Azucena Villaflor

Štefan Krčméry

Štefan Krčméry (pseudonyms Eška, Ján Jesom, Ujo Štefan et al.) (26 December 1892 – 17 February 1955) was a Slovak poet, literary critic, historian, journalist, translator, and administrator of Matica slovenská.

See Chaplain and Štefan Krčméry

Backstretch

Backstretch refers to either: (1) the portion of an oval racetrack on the far side of the grandstand, parallel to the homestretch, or, (2) particularly in North America, the area near the racetrack where horses are stabled and the daily work of maintaining the horses occurs.

See Chaplain and Backstretch

Balsall Preceptory

Balsall Preceptory in Warwickshire was a manor that was given to the Knights Templars in recognition of their service in the Crusades.

See Chaplain and Balsall Preceptory

Baltimore Police Department

The Baltimore Police Department (BPD) provides police services to the city of Baltimore, Maryland.

See Chaplain and Baltimore Police Department

Bancroft Hall

Bancroft Hall at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Maryland, is the largest single dormitory in the world.

See Chaplain and Bancroft Hall

Baron Petre

Baron Petre (pronounced Peter), of Writtle, in the County of Essex, is a title in the Peerage of England.

See Chaplain and Baron Petre

Barry Morgan

Barry Cennydd Morgan (born 31 January 1947) is a Welsh Anglican bishop and academic.

See Chaplain and Barry Morgan

Bartholomaeus Pitiscus

Bartholomaeus Pitiscus (also Barthélemy, Bartholomeo, August 24, 1561 – July 2, 1613) was a 16th-century German trigonometrist, astronomer and theologian who first coined the word trigonometry.

See Chaplain and Bartholomaeus Pitiscus

Basoche

The Basoche was the guild of legal clerks of the Paris court system under the pre-revolutionary French monarchy, from among whom legal representatives (procureurs) were recruited.

See Chaplain and Basoche

Battle of Gaines's Mill

The Battle of Gaines's Mill, sometimes known as the First Battle of Cold Harbor or the Battle of Chickahominy River, took place on June 27, 1862, in Hanover County, Virginia, as the third of the Seven Days Battles (Peninsula Campaign) of the American Civil War.

See Chaplain and Battle of Gaines's Mill

Battle of Ogdensburg

The Battle of Ogdensburg was a battle of the War of 1812.

See Chaplain and Battle of Ogdensburg

Battle of Pusan Perimeter

The Battle of Pusan Perimeter was a large-scale battle between United Nations and North Korean forces lasting from August 4 to September 18, 1950.

See Chaplain and Battle of Pusan Perimeter

Battle of Springfield (1780)

The Battle of Springfield was fought during the American Revolutionary War on June 23, 1780.

See Chaplain and Battle of Springfield (1780)

Beadsman

Bedesman, or beadsman (Med. Eng. bede, prayer, from O. Eng. biddan, to pray; literally "a man of prayer"; and from Anglo Saxon "bed") was generally a pensioner or almsman whose duty it was to pray for his benefactor.

See Chaplain and Beadsman

Beilby Porteus

Beilby Porteus (or Porteous; 8 May 1731 – 13 May 1809), successively Bishop of Chester and of London, was a Church of England reformer and a leading abolitionist in England.

See Chaplain and Beilby Porteus

Benedictional of St. Æthelwold

The Benedictional of St.

See Chaplain and Benedictional of St. Æthelwold

Benito Arias Montano

Benito Arias Montano (or Benedictus Arias Montanus; 1527–1598) was a Spanish orientalist and editor of the Antwerp Polyglot.

See Chaplain and Benito Arias Montano

Benjamin Randall

Benjamin Randall (February 7, 1749 - October 22, 1808) was the main organizer of the Freewill Baptists (Randall Line) in the northeastern United States.

See Chaplain and Benjamin Randall

Bernard Jungmann

Bernard Jungmann was a German Catholic dogmatic theologian and ecclesiastical historian.

See Chaplain and Bernard Jungmann

Bernardus Compostellanus Junior

Bernard of Compostella (Bernardus Compostellanus Junior or Modernus) lived in the middle of the thirteenth century, called Compostellanus from the fact that he possessed an ecclesiastical benefice in Compostella.

See Chaplain and Bernardus Compostellanus Junior

Bernhard Schwentner

Bernhard Schwentner (28 September 1891 in Schwerin – 30 October 1944 near Brandenburg-Görden) was a German Catholic clergyman.

See Chaplain and Bernhard Schwentner

Bertram Korn

Bertram Wallace Korn, Sr.

See Chaplain and Bertram Korn

Beta Upsilon Chi

Beta Upsilon Chi (ΒΥΧ), is the largest Christian social fraternity in the United States.

See Chaplain and Beta Upsilon Chi

Billy Graham

William Franklin Graham Jr. (November 7, 1918 – February 21, 2018) was an American evangelist, a prominent evangelical Christian figure, and an ordained Southern Baptist minister who became well known internationally in the late 1940s.

See Chaplain and Billy Graham

Bishop

A bishop (English derivation from the New Testament of the Christian Bible Greek επίσκοπος, epískopos, "overseer", "guardian") is an ordained, consecrated, or appointed member of the Christian clergy who is generally entrusted with a position of authority and oversight.

See Chaplain and Bishop

Bishop Cotton Boys' School

Bishop Cotton Boys' School is an all-boys school for boarders and day scholars in Bangalore, India, founded in memory of Bishop George Edward Lynch Cotton, Bishop of Calcutta.

See Chaplain and Bishop Cotton Boys' School

Bishop of Bath and Wells

The Bishop of Bath and Wells heads the Church of England Diocese of Bath and Wells in the Province of Canterbury in England.

See Chaplain and Bishop of Bath and Wells

Bishop of Paisley

The Bishop of Paisley is the Ordinary of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paisley in the Province of Glasgow, Scotland.

See Chaplain and Bishop of Paisley

Bishop Stopford's School

Bishop Stopford's School, commonly known as Bishop Stopford's, or (locally) just Bishop's, is a voluntary aided co-educational secondary school specialising in mathematics, computing and engineering, with a sixth form.

See Chaplain and Bishop Stopford's School

Black dog (ghost)

A black dog is a spectral or demonic entity found primarily in the folklore of the British Isles.

See Chaplain and Black dog (ghost)

Blind Harry

Blind Harry (1440 – 1492), also known as Harry, Hary or Henry the Minstrel, is renowned as the author of The Actes and Deidis of the Illustre and Vallyeant Campioun Schir William Wallace, more commonly known as The Wallace.

See Chaplain and Blind Harry

Borgvattnet

Borgvattnet is a small village in Ragunda Municipality in northern Sweden.

See Chaplain and Borgvattnet

Brendan O'Brien (bishop)

Brendan Michael O'Brien (born September 28, 1943) is a Canadian prelate of the Roman Catholic Church.

See Chaplain and Brendan O'Brien (bishop)

Bridgettines

The Order of the Most Holy Savior, abbreviated as O.Ss.S., and informally known as the Brigittine or Bridgettine Order is a monastic religious order of Augustinian nuns, Religious Sisters, and monks founded by Saint Bridget of Sweden (Birgitta) in 1344, and approved by Pope Urban V in 1370.

See Chaplain and Bridgettines

Brigade

A brigade is a major tactical military formation that is typically composed of three to six battalions plus supporting elements.

See Chaplain and Brigade

Brione (Verzasca)

Brione (Verzasca) is a municipality in the district of Locarno in the canton of Ticino in Switzerland.

See Chaplain and Brione (Verzasca)

Brione sopra Minusio

Brione sopra Minusio is a municipality in the district of Locarno in the canton of Ticino in Switzerland.

See Chaplain and Brione sopra Minusio

British industrial mission

British industrial mission is a network of ordained and lay chaplains who provide ministry to people in paid employment.

See Chaplain and British industrial mission

Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen

The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen (B of LF&E) was a North American railroad fraternal benefit society and trade union in the 19th and 20th centuries.

See Chaplain and Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen

Bruce Cameron (bishop)

Andrew Bruce Cameron (born 2 May 1941) is a Scottish Anglican bishop who served as the Bishop of Aberdeen and Orkney and the Primus of the Scottish Episcopal Church.

See Chaplain and Bruce Cameron (bishop)

Buddhist Churches of America

The is the United States branch of the Nishi Honganji subsect of Jōdo Shinshū ("True Pure Land School") Buddhism.

See Chaplain and Buddhist Churches of America

Buddhist Peace Fellowship

The Buddhist Peace Fellowship (BPF) is a nonsectarian international network of engaged Buddhists participating in various forms of nonviolent social activism and environmentalism.

See Chaplain and Buddhist Peace Fellowship

Burman University

Burman University is an independent publicly funded university located in Lacombe, Alberta, Canada.

See Chaplain and Burman University

Bury St Edmunds Abbey

The Abbey of Bury St Edmunds was once among the richest Benedictine monasteries in England, until the Dissolution of the monasteries in 1539.

See Chaplain and Bury St Edmunds Abbey

Bushmead Priory

The Priory Church of Saint Mary, Bushmead, commonly called Bushmead Priory, was a monastic foundation for Augustinian Canons, located at Bushmead (a Hamlet in Staploe parish) in the County of Bedfordshire in England.

See Chaplain and Bushmead Priory

Butuan

(pronounced), officially the (Butuanon: Dakbayan hong; name; name), or simply known as City, is a highly urbanized city and regional center of the Caraga Region,.

See Chaplain and Butuan

Caesar Otway

Caesar Otway (1780–1842) was born at Castle Otway near Nenagh, Co.

See Chaplain and Caesar Otway

California State Assembly

The California State Assembly is the lower house of the California State Legislature.

See Chaplain and California State Assembly

California State Senate

The California State Senate is the upper house of the California State Legislature.

See Chaplain and California State Senate

Calvary Cemetery (Los Angeles)

Calvary Cemetery is a Roman Catholic cemetery that the Archdiocese of Los Angeles runs in the community of East Los Angeles.

See Chaplain and Calvary Cemetery (Los Angeles)

Cambuslang clergy

The sequence of the Cambuslang clergy reflects pretty accurately the development of the Christian Church in Cambuslang, Scotland.

See Chaplain and Cambuslang clergy

Camp Atterbury

Camp Atterbury, located in south-central Indiana, about west of Edinburgh, Indiana, serves as a military and civilian training base under the auspices of the Indiana National Guard.

See Chaplain and Camp Atterbury

Canterbury, New South Wales

Canterbury is a suburb extending across south-western Sydney and the Inner West, in the state of New South Wales, Australia.

See Chaplain and Canterbury, New South Wales

Carl Cooper

Carl Cooper (born 1960) is a former Anglican bishop who was the Bishop of St. David's from 2002 to 2008.

See Chaplain and Carl Cooper

Carlos Arredondo

Carlos Alexander Brian Arredondo (born Carlos Luis de Los Ángeles Arredondo Piedra; August 25, 1960) is a Costa Rican-American peace activist and an American Red Cross volunteer.

See Chaplain and Carlos Arredondo

Carlos Sommervogel

Carlos Sommervogel (8 January 1834 – 4 March 1902) was a French Jesuit scholar.

See Chaplain and Carlos Sommervogel

Catholic Church in Sweden

The Catholic Church in Sweden was established by Archbishop Ansgar in Birka in 829, and further developed by the Christianization of Sweden in the 9th century.

See Chaplain and Catholic Church in Sweden

Catholic Church in Thailand

The Catholic Church in Thailand is part of the worldwide Catholic Church, under the spiritual leadership of the Pope in Rome.

See Chaplain and Catholic Church in Thailand

Cavendish banana

A Cavendish banana is the fruit of a banana cultivar belonging to the Cavendish subgroup of the AAA cultivar group.

See Chaplain and Cavendish banana

Cazenovia Seminary

Cazenovia Seminary was an academic (not exclusively theological) seminary (like an early high school) of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

See Chaplain and Cazenovia Seminary

Celso Benigno Luigi Costantini

Celso Benigno Luigi Costantini (3 April 1876 – 17 October 1958) was an Italian Roman Catholic cardinal and the founder of the Disciples of the Lord who served as the Apostolic Chancellor from 1954 until his death.

See Chaplain and Celso Benigno Luigi Costantini

Chaplain Extraordinary

A chaplain in extraordinary was a chaplain appointed to the Household of the British crown.

See Chaplain and Chaplain Extraordinary

Chaplain Tappman

Chaplain Captain Albert Taylor Tappman (A.T. Tappman) (usually referred to as "the Chaplain") is a fictional character in Joseph Heller's novel Catch-22.

See Chaplain and Chaplain Tappman

Chaplin

Chaplin may refer to.

See Chaplain and Chaplin

Chappel

Chappel is a village and civil parish in the borough of Colchester, Essex which sits on the River Colne.

See Chaplain and Chappel

Charles Cardwell McCabe

Charles Cardwell McCabe (October 11, 1836 – December 19, 1906) was an American who distinguished himself as a Methodist pastor, an Army chaplain during the American Civil War, a Church executive chiefly in the field of fundraising, as Chancellor of American University, and as a Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church (M.E.), elected in 1896.

See Chaplain and Charles Cardwell McCabe

Charles H. Colton

Charles Henry Colton (October 15, 1848 – May 9, 1915) was an American clergyman of the Roman Catholic Church.

See Chaplain and Charles H. Colton

Charles Hudson (climber)

Charles Hudson (4 October 1828 – 14 July 1865) was an Anglican chaplain and mountain climber from Skillington, Lincolnshire, England.
